column1: Before 15 March 2020, will the parliament of New Zealand pass a bill that would create a national gun register?
column6: ['Non-US Politics']
Drastically reducing my forecast based on recent news.
Not enough time left. https://www.newsweek.com/2020/03/13/gun-control-efforts-have-stalled-one-year-after-christchurch-mosque-killings-1492069.html
It's Friday the 13th in New Zealand - they're not in session today or tomorrow, so there's no possible way this gets passed before the question ends.
Winston Peter's electioneering has made this goal impossible.
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/mar/12/new-zealand-gun-reform-stalled-as-christchurch-anniversary-approaches
Recent news says it’s not a priority and the government is split. With only a few days to go it won’t happen in time. The guardian goes as far as saying that it isn’t going to happen
Looks like they are continuing to push the decision.
Politics 6 Mar 2020 Gun reforms: Government split over second phase of legislation 5:34 am on 6 March 2020 Share this
https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/political/411063/gun-reforms-government-split-over-second-phase-of-legislation
They’re not debating it today
Not this soon.
Going back to a soft comfortable zero for the rest of the week at least. Echoing the sentiments of @Bengreat and @Benjamin-Yeoh.
Judging from how the debate is going their most likely going to take the debate beyond March 15 2019
Chances that they will reach an agreement by March 15 appear to have decreased significantly.
Stalled and give now saying 15 March not the important thing but correct compromises/law is important. (Media reports.)
Ain't gonna happen.
Cutting my forecast in half as it appears to be meeting some resistance with no movement this week likely.
Per recent news reports (previous forecasts) will probably need to lower forecast further, soon
https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/political/411063/gun-reforms-government-split-over-second-phase-of-legislation
Just listened to an interview with Peters and he is looking to take pro-gun votes from ACT.
Winnie Peters is playing the populist card as the election looms and New Zealand first is not polling well.
It is unclear how long it may take but the bill is not expected to pass before the first anniversary of the Christchurch shooting on March 15, which had been the Government's initial preference.

Lowering this as while discussions have been taking place- it seems votes could go either way. I was up around 50% so decided to take a stance! I do think they will pass the bill but the vote has been delayed- so not sure it will take place before 15 march.
Does not appear to be prioritised on the order paper https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/order-paper-questions/order-paper/document/OrderPaper_20200304/final-order-paper-for-wednesday-04-march-2020

The second part of the firearm law reform will be debated in Parliament this week. Reports say vote could go either way. https://www.tvnz.co.nz/one-news/new-zealand/do-right-thing-gun-registry-advocates-opponents-look-convince-nz-first-likely-have-deciding-vote https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12309787

On Saturday 29 February, the President of the NZ Police Association stated: “This time next week, all going well, Parliament will have passed the Arms Legislation Bill as the second tranche of firearms reforms designed to make all New Zealanders safer.”
3/2/20 article (link): I'm still seeing conflicting reports about the status of the legislation. https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12313236

NZ First supposedly 'on the fence' but so far have supported the bill all the way through to its second reading. I believe this is more political posturing to their base than an abrupt U turn. It would be very late in the day not to support a bill they have helped to put together and supported.
NZ First is wavering
(IV) Updating based on article found by Benjamin-Yeoh and confirmations in forecast changes made by bobrown.

(OV) I'm coming into this forecast late. I'm selecting %65 as my baseline as it's close to the "priced in" forecast value from the team. I'll start evaluating inside view (IV) and outside view (OV) information from this point forward.
Cutting my forecast in half again based on the update from @Benjamin-Yeoh. The will is there, just not the time to incorporate all concerns.
Watching pertinent developments this coming week

I've changed my mind due to this report: "NZ First may choose to join the National Party and the ACT Party by putting up amendments to the Bill during the committee of the whole House, when the House adjourns on March 3.

The bill is due its third and final reading in the first week of March. It rests on NZ first supporting the bill. NZ First supported second reading but are being lobbied hard, and asked for some changes. There's also an inquiry publication later in March, which NZ First might say to wait for. HOWEVER, the PM is pushing hard and most of NZ still have memories of the tragedy last year, so I will put as likely the bill will pass.
Cutting forecast in half as no news on progress and days are short to March 14.
Dropping forecast below 50% for now on the shortening (question) time period, conflicting publicly-available assessments + lack of up-to-date info., and vocal public opposition to gun registry.
Braking and downshifting as momentum has been lost for a March 14 date.
I think it will happen, but there isn't enough time b/w now and 15 March
Just not in this time frame. https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/political/409958/further-changes-to-firearms-bill-likely-before-becoming-law

Crucial coalition discussion wont occur until the 9th, and following that, there is not enough time in Parliament to pass SOPs or rejigged Bill. Tellingly, Ardern has dropped all reference to the Bill this year. The Bill doesn't have anything in it that addresses the March 15 shooting, so could be politically embarrassing. They can mark the 15 Mar anniversary adequately without the Bill.
Down shifting as some of the momentum may have been lost as bill gets closer review. Likely to pass but less likely by the stated date.

Dropping the forecast by 1%. According to the article below, NZ Police Minister Stuart Nash is in talks with parties that have concerns with the bill, but the bill may not pass before 15 Mar, which is Nash's preference. We should have updates nlt 3 Mar after the House adjourns.
Revising upwards. Looks like it is moving closer to being passed. It appears to be a watered down version of the proposed law, but it will still have the gun registry.

Lowering forecast again for now -- mainly reflecting a shortening question time period -- after a conflicting news/analysis report about the bill's prospects of passing by 3/15/20: "...It is unclear how long this may take but the Bill is not expected to pass before the first anniversary of the Christchurch shooting on March 15, which had been Nash's preference."
The Second Reading was yesterday. The bill is huge - over 100 pages long. Link on this page;

Increasing from 75% to 85% based on the fact the bill passed its second reading today in NZ's Parliament. Increasing likelihood: Today's reading was passed 63 in favor to 57 opposed along party lines. Assuming the final legislation requires a simple majority, the odds are very good it'll get through final vote. Uncertainty: There are several aspects of the bill that are still hotly contested. Here's a NZ Natl Party speech that sums them up (https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/tab/video). Depending on how much NZers care about these issues, the CoH and 3rd readings might get more contentious.
Increased to 75% due to the bill passing the second reading. The bill is on track for 15 Mar.
Rollin' Rollin' Rollin' https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/arms-legislation-bill

Moving closer to the current 'crowd' forecast with the bill passing its second reading and continued government push for its passage. Balanced (mainly) with significant written (etc.) opposition + the question's relatively short remaining time period. Will continue to monitor and update forecast as needed.
The Bill is progressing through Parliament. Second reading was yesterday. https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/tab/sop
Passed 2nd reading and is now in CoH stage - will likely pass-through final stages and be given Royal Assent by the 15th March.
Further progress noted, from a second reading, to the penultimate step before a final vote.
passed second reading, CoH tomorrow
https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12309787

Increasing to 62% given that the content of the bill has been reduced. I'll update again after the second reading, which is scheduled for today. If the bill makes it through the 2nd reading, then there is a strong chance it will be passed by the symbolic date of 15 Mar.

Input from others have given me renewed backbone to increase my forecast. The watering down may have smoothed some of the bill's rougher edges. If it actually gets read this week, then I'll move higher. https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/arms-legislation-bill

starting this forecast at just over 50/50 due to time frame that remains for passage of legislation. Last semi-automatic weapons ban took 26 days to pass. With just under 30 days remaining to pass legislation, it is possible but I would need to see more movement into 2nd reading to be more confident that it will pass the bill for a gun register.
Second reading of a bill possible Feb 18th. Will check on it then. If passed on to third reading I will radically change orediction.
A little closer to the current overall 'crowd's forecast, pending further information.

True, but this question regards the legislation. The Select Committee's decision to remove accessories from the Registry requirement lessens the bill's bureaucratic burden and thus makes it more likely to pass through Parliament.

But Gun Control NZ says the Arms Legislation Bill has been watered down too much, and is calling the loosening of proposed advertising restrictions a cop-out. The bill is expected to have its second reading next week. https://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=12308070
Good article clarifying (I think) the edits the Select Committee made to the DRAFT Arms Legislation Bill. https://www.sunlive.co.nz/blogs/14360-firearms-legislation-change-is-happening.html
The second reading of the bill is on the order paper for Tuesday next week, 18 Feb 2020;

Before 15 March 2020, will the parliament of New Zealand pass a bill that would create a national gun register? I am dropping my forecast as have others, not for the spirit but for the remaining few days available to complete the process.

I'm increasing my forecast based on recent news regarding the review and re-reading of the bill. However, I continue to think passing of the bill by 15 March 2020 is unlikely as the steps to passing a bill (Introduction, First reading, Select committee, Second reading, Committee of the whole House, Third reading, and Royal assent) aren't 50% complete.
I'm decreasing my forecast by 1%. Numerous have cited this article: https://www.parliament.nz/en/get-involved/topics/all-current-topics/bill-proposes-further-tightening-of-gun-controls/#
Refs;
Not enough time.

Bill was reviewed by the Finance and Expenditure Committee and sent back with numerous recommended changes, all of them lessening the strictness of the bill. It will be re-read this week. The proposed changes have frustrated gun control advocates who see them as "watering down" the intent of the bill; in fact, the National Party wrote a minority report that did not recommend the bill in its current form. Nonetheless, it seems more likely than not that the majority will okay the proposed changes or quickly reach a compromise on any particular issue. Gun Control is a popular, common sense idea in New Zealand - consider that the original vote in April 2019 passed Parliament 119-1.
The bill is out of committee and has popular support. I believe it will eventually pass, but it may not be before 15 March

The relevant Arms Legislation Bill has progressed from its Select Committee to a second reading, which should involve debate and a full house vote. https://www.parliament.nz/en/get-involved/topics/all-current-topics/bill-proposes-further-tightening-of-gun-controls/#

The act is popular amongst most New Zealand residents according to media sources. Additionally, March 2020 will be the anniversary of the Christchurch shooting which directly inspired the beginning of this legislation. Within the Parliament, the act was passed with amendments and seemingly no public outcry against it. Furthermore, Gun legislation has become something of a point of pride in New Zealand because of the quick action taken by the government in 2019. The only reason I predict this outcome as under 70% is because of the speed of the actions taken in 2019 and the issues this caused (specifically with the buyback program). Throughout New Zealand history there have been multiple registries that were less encompassing then the one proposed. I believe the government will choose to roll out this act slower and more completely. They may have it prepared by March but they may wait to begin implementation past the anniversary.
"The Finance and Expenditure Committee has examined the Arms Legislation Bill and recommends by majority that it be passed with the amendments shown."
The bill with amendments has made it out of committee. You can find the amendments here: https://www.parliament.nz/resource/en-NZ/SCR_93759/dc0896032262699f1094f5c39f08df21c2c19a9f

Lowering to around 50-50 for now, pending updates on the legislation's progress. As noted by other forecasters there appears to be significant opposition to the bill via public comments: https://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/PO2002/S00057/a-mere-7-support-arms-bill.htm
It will be interesting to see what happens, if anything in the next committee session on Friday, 7 Feb https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/sc/schedule-of-meetings/

Before 15 March 2020, will the parliament of New Zealand pass a bill that would create a national gun register? Do the homework and read the 4K objections to the proposed firearms bill at the website https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/tab/submissionsandadvice?Criteria.PageNumber=25 This is an election year with the focus turning elsewhere perhaps. https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/arms-legislation-bill
Feeling less confident about the significance of the anniversary date. Not finding any new information about this topic.

New elections are called for September. This is controversial so unlikely to be passed by this date. I see the PM calling for a registry but no articles that say it has passed or is near. https://www.newstalkzb.co.nz/on-air/mike-hosking-breakfast/audio/chris-cahill-new-figures-on-firearm-seizures-boosts-calls-for-a-national-gun-registry/
New Zealand Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern confirmed the reforms to gun laws will be announced by March 25.
While there appears to be a fair amount of support, it is an election year in New Zealand.

Establishing a base rate for this question is a bit challenging. After gun laws in various countries, it is clear that of the 195 countries in the world, most have a gun registry. Additionally, most developed nations have some form of registry as well, which places the base rate conservatively around 70%.
Before 15 March 2020, will the parliament of New Zealand pass a bill that would create a national gun register? I find nothing in the New Zealand press.

Having suffered the March 2019 attacks in Christchurch, the New Zeland populace are supporting the national gun register, but there are still oppositions. The Parliament of New Zeland will probably pass the bill.
The Aussies did it and the Kiwis haven't forgotten.
Reality will prevail.
Adjusting downward due to uncertainty in the NZ legislative calendar.

I started out by trying to calculate the percentage of countries in the world that have gun registries. According to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Overview_of_gun_laws_by_nation, of the 116 countries they list about 87% (I may have counted slightly off) have full gun registries (like the one proposed), a couple have no registry, and the remainder have registries dependent on type of gun, region, etc. However, it's not clear whether the remainder of countries not listed (primarily African, Central Asian, and some Central and South American) mostly do or do not have registries, so it's a slightly flawed starting place. So I'll un-extremize this base rate a bit to account for that uncertainty, and say perhaps 80% of total countries have similar registries, which would be the base rate if 50% of the unaccounted for countries had gun registries (if I had more time I could do this properly).

Base rate: - Difficult to determine here. We could look at the percentage of NZ Parliament bills (over the past 5-10 years, maybe) in the Select Committee stage which make it to the Royal Assent stage within 2 months. Or the percentage of NZ Parliament bills (over the past 5-10 years) in the First Reading stage which make it to the Royal Assent stage within 6 months -- the bill was introduced to First Reading in Sep 2019, which is about 6 months before this question's deadline of March 15th 2020. - I don't have this data offhand, but theoretically it could be determined using data from the NZ Parliament: https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/all
The report from the Select Committee isn't due until February 10th.
NZ MPs voted 119-1 to outlaw most semiautomatic weapons and assault rifles in April 19
Even though there is some resistance, popular support in New Zealand seems interested in further gun control legislation.

UK, Australia, and Canada instituted reforms including registration requirements shortly after gun-related tragedies. New Zealand’s political system can allow for rapid passage of legislation, e.g., the initial measures after the Christchurch attacks. The one year anniversary of those attacks could be a symbolic deadline, yet the passage of time without progress on this effort suggests momentum for reform is lagging. Struggled to find an analogous base rate for something as specific as a national registry following gun attacks given that initial reforms have already been implemented; registration requirements are very common globally, and vary in the specifics.
First forecast
I primarily researched 4 things:
Lowering forecast to 'crowd' level for now, as unable to locate much new, credible info. re this question.

The timing seems unlikely. Proposal of the bill appears to have been a gut reaction and the third/fourth order affects of the registry are now being contemplated, as well as whether the proposal would actually resolve the problem it is trying to solve.
They are still talking about it but some powerful political parties oppose. Do not see it happening that quickly as I can find no pending vote.
Dropping from 15 to 5.
Crowd forecast, need to do more research.
Before 15 March 2020, will the parliament of New Zealand pass a bill that would create a national gun register? Maybe someday, but doubtful in the next 2 months.
Affirming for now, with not much enlightening news found re this topic recently.
It will take inspiration from Australia's similar response to its mass shootings. It will happen, I'm just not sure if that will be by March 15.

So, obviously the international gun community is pointing out the similarity in the two church shootings situations, the one of course at their Mosque and Ours in Texas. Very different outcomes. New Z gun control activist immediately pointed out that the man Jack Wilson shot in the head (which he has also been criticized for - however as video replay and his interview show and tell - One MEMBER - A ELDERLY LADY -HAD RISEN UP LEAVING HIM ONLY A HEAD SHOT AND EXTENDING HI REATION TIME TO THREE SECONDS FROM <2) sO THE CONVERSATION THEIR HAS MATURED AND WE'LL SEE WHICH WAY IT BREAKS AGAIN IN Feb. Of course events could overtake the question easily in this time frame.
Before 15 March 2020, will the parliament of New Zealand pass a bill that would create a national gun register? Walking my forecast down in sympathy with @Hammer-Time.
Reducing. NZ would be wise to review the cost ($ and politically). Easier to legislate certain types of weapons.

Before 15 March 2020, will the parliament of New Zealand pass a bill that would create a national gun register? OK, OK, I'll increase my odds, but registration may be more expensive than anticiopated and less effective.
All guns laws across the board are being tightened and more strictly enforced.

Before 15 March 2020, will the parliament of New Zealand pass a bill that would create a national gun register? Lots of good analysis, but will a registry become part of any new law. Not clear if the cost of implementation matches the perceived benefit. While I second the emotion of tighter constraints on fire arms, I am not sure registration is the way forward in the timeframe of this question.

I’m coming down slightly based on. . NZ and Ardern have already taken action (quickly based on Christchurch attack) . Ardern (Labour) leads a minority government (operating as coalition) . Unclear if NZ First (part of coalition) will go along given resistance in rural areas to registration . Nationals (more seats than Labour and strong in rural area) may not support New Zealand can look to other countries and see registries can be pricey and don’t stop criminals from getting guns. Restrictions and penalties are cheaper to implement and don’t alienate more conservative voters. Will keep an eye on this...
The Government's Finance and Expenditure Committee is currently calling for submissions on the Bill, which has passed its first reading in Parliament.
The first round of reforms, already passed into law, outlawed most military-style semi-automatics and assault rifles.

This seems probably, and the parliament seems to be moving the bill along quickly. However, the coalition partner is opposed and so my main doubts are over the timeline. I suspect it will take longer to get votes together for the bill than expected and that will delay things.

It would seem like the majority of the New Zealand parliament are for sensible gun control. So far the push back from the opposition has not been on inflexible ideological grounds. Since the "iron is still hot" with the massacre having occurred a few months ago, it is likely that, at least, a watered down version of the proposed bill will reach and get a royal assent

Taking into account earlier comments made by @KitsonJ, @nonplus and others for an initial forecast. Noting that the (NZ) National party has now expressed opposition to the current bill. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arms_Legislation_Bill_2019, https://www.stuff.co.nz/national/116470813/national-is-opposed-to-firearms-bill-after-most-changes-it-requested-are-declined).
I think they will do this as they think it's the right thing to do.
>Police minister Stuart Nash says the Select Committee considering the bill is now expected to report back by February 10 next year.
The government proposed it, they have a majority, and Kiwis unlike USAmericans are tired of massacres. Shouldn't be a big problem--although there will be grumbling, some of it justified.

The Government, who introduced the bill, has a working majority in the House (a coalition of the Labour, NZ First + a confidence and supply agreement with the Green party) of 6. It passed the first reading with the full 6 working majority. It has been referred to the Finance and Expenditure Committee, where the Lab/NZ First have a majority. ( https://www.parliament.nz/en/pb/bills-and-laws/bills-proposed-laws/document/BILL_91272/arms-legislation-bill)
